text:
$TSLA Optimus Gen 2 costs ~$50-$60K in hardware per unit.

When the hardware BoM is already in this range it signals a path toward mass production & the same learning curves that reshaped the EV cost structure.

Most of the cost is in components Tesla already knows how to scale so as volumes increase the base cost falls & the software layer becomes the massive margin driver.

This is the early stage of a product that eventually becomes cheaper than human labor on a per hour basis.

$MSFT & $ORCL are heavily tethered to OpenAI for their AI backlog.

$AMZN is building AI demand without that dependence which makes AWS growth cleaner while the other two look like a leveraged bet on OpenAI.

This chart basically sums up 2025 where the market is rewarding the extremes & ignoring everything in the middle.

The market is paying up for early category leaders in AI, space, quantum & nuclear because the policy backdrop is creating a demand vacuum that pulls those themes forward faster than anyone expected.

At the same time the Mag-7 keep getting rerated as the long-term toll booths of the AI economy since they own the compute, data & distribution layers everyone else has to build on.

Everything outside those buckets is stuck in the middle where you are either exposed to GenAI disruption or not tied to a theme strong enough to matter when multiple super-cycles begin compounding at once.

$BMNR now holds about 3.2% of all Ethereum.

They added ~139K $ETH last week binging their total to ~3.86M.

OpenAI‚Äôs new data shows that users saving more than 10 hours a week consume 8x the compute of light users so the real productivity shows up only when AI becomes part of the core workflow.

The AI economy will concentrate in platforms that can drive high-intensity usage:

‚Ä¢ $NET Edge inference & global AI delivery
‚Ä¢ $GOOGL Gemini usage spanning search, Workspace & Cloud
‚Ä¢ $AMZN Bedrock model consumption & AWS agent workloads
‚Ä¢ $PLTR Decision-layer systems that expand as workflows deepen
‚Ä¢ $META AI agents embedded across messaging, feeds & commerce
‚Ä¢ $MSFT Copilot integrated into Office, Windows & enterprise productivity
‚Ä¢ $SNOW Retrieval & data processing that scale with continuous model activity
‚Ä¢ $CRWD Autonomous security workflows that grow with agent-driven detection
The timing of this post couldn‚Äôt be better with the news that $IBM is buying $CFLT  üëÄ

$CRWV is raising $2B in convertible notes due 2031 with another $300M option for buyers

They have to keep doing deals like this because every GPU clusters, networking & power buildouts are massively expensive & must be done ahead of customer demand

This won‚Äôt be the last raise

$GOOGL & $NEE are partnering on multi-gigawatt U.S. data center campuses with dedicated power for accelerating AI demand.

The first three sites are already in development with ~3.5 GW operating or contracted.
$IBM IS BUYING $CFLT FOR $11B

$HOOD is expanding into Indonesia.

The company is acquiring Buana Capital Sekuritas & a licensed crypto trader to enter a market with 19M capital-market investors & 17M crypto traders.

AI chip demand is running far hotter than expected.

$TSM CoWoS lines are overflowing because $NVDA, $GOOGL & $AMZN are pulling forward so much GPU & custom-silicon volume that even the recent capacity expansions cannot keep up. 

The company is now outsourcing part of its CoWoS packaging to ASE (which is typically a last resort) & it shows that demand is running well ahead of what the supply chain can deliver.

Elon Musk saying that the next leg of AI scaling won‚Äôt come from squeezing more power on Earth but from adding compute through low-cost satellites that plug directly into Starlink.

The market is completely mispricing how explosive the space economy is about to get over the next 5 years. 

$RKLB can put the hardware up there & $ASTS can move the data if space-based compute actually happens

AI training and inference are projected to account for almost 40% of the US‚Äô total data center capacity by 2035, per BloombergNEF, driving data center utilization 10 points higher, from 59% to 69%. 

$NVDA $AMD $MSFT $GOOG $AMZN $ORCL

Morgan Stanley now projects data centers needing 72GW of power from 2025 through 2028, with the potential power shortfall widening from 44GW to 47GW.

$MSFT $AMZN $GOOG $ORCL

The firm estimates that ‚Äòtime to power‚Äô solutions could help bridge the gap, with 15-20GW from gas turbines, 5-8GW from fuel cells and 10-15GW from Bitcoin sites. 

$BE $IREN $APLD $NVDA

üì∫ MY TOP WEEKLY SETUPS: $GOOGL, $META, AND A SURPRISE PLAY

Google and Meta are delivering some of the strongest defined-risk setups of the week, with IREN adding a potential catalyst-driven surprise. 

In this short video, I break down why these three trades stand out and how to approach them.

üì∫ WHY $TSLA PULLBACK MIGHT BE THE GIFT TRADERS WAITED FOR

$TSLA downgrade triggered a normal pullback after a big run, but key levels at $445‚Äì$438 could turn it into an opportunity. 

In this short video, I highlight why this dip may set up a potential year-end continuation move for traders looking to re-engage.

üì∫ FED WEEK: CALM BEFORE THE BREAKOUT‚Ä¶ OR BREAKDOWN?

The market is stretched heading into the Fed meeting, and everything now depends on whether the rate cut is seen as dovish or hawkish.

A dovish cut could extend the rally into Christmas, while a hawkish one may spark a shakeout.

In this short video, I break down key levels for $SPY / $QQQ that will guide the reaction.

$SPX confirmed the Thanksgiving rally and tagged 6895. Big question now: do we get a ‚Äúsell the news‚Äù hawkish cut or push to fresh ATHs above 6920 into the holidays, with 6799 as key upper support.
